Description: Limestone figures of two uraeus cobras. Both cobras wear the sun-disc crowns, and their eyes are simplistically rendered. Their hoods appear to not have any incised detail, though the lower portion of their bodies include two additional small uraeus cobra figures that wear sun-disc crowns with cow horns. Their lower bodies are raised up behind them and their tails are curled at the back. The right side cobra’s lower body has been damaged at the reverse, and the back of the base is also partly missing. The surface of the limestone is heavily damaged and worn, with clear flaking across both the bodies of the cobras and across the sides of the base. The object is now supported by a thin modern base.
Curator's comments: Depictions of double uraei is particularly found in later royal representations, but in earlier cases two cobras could be shown with one wearing the White Crown of Upper Egypt and the other cobra wearing the Red Crown of Lower Egypt. Here in this case, they may instead indicate the later trend of the first millennium BC for two uraeus cobras to adorn a king’s nemes headdress or crown.
